metadata./Title: Interdisciplinary care of facial plexiform neurofibroma: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Neurofibromatosis is considered a rare genetic disorder primarily affecting neural tissues. The most 
common type is neurofibromatosis type 1, which is characterized by plexiform neurofibromas.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report a case of a 30-year-old Rag-lay ethnic woman with facial plexiform neurofibroma, 
which not only infiltrated the left eye socket but also caused destruction of temporal bone and facial deformity. The 
disease started in her childhood, and she had numerous neurofibromas on her trunk and limb at the time of the hospital admission. The patient was diagnosed with neurofibromatosis 1 based on clinical symptoms, computed tomography images, and histopathologic result. For safety, we divided treatment into two phases. For the first phase, we 
dealt with the blood supply and meningeal suture, and then we performed surgical resection and skin flap reconstruction surgery.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion The main therapy for plexiform neurofibroma is surgery, which aims at tumor removal and management 
of complications. However, the treatment plan is different in each case based on the nature and extent of tumor, 
which requires more verification and clinical practice.
Keywords  Neurofibromatosis type 1, Facial neurofibroma, Endovascular intervention, Skin flap reconstruction

Background
Neurofibromatosis is a rare genetic disorder that affects 
neural tissues and is characterized by the growth of 
tumors on nerves all over the body at any stage of life [1]. 
However, the disease usually develops during childhood 
and could progress to significant morbidity or mortality. 
Two distinct forms are recognized, though they may be variant forms. Neurofibromatosis 1 or NF-1 (previously 
known as peripheral neurofibromatosis) is characterized 
by café-au-lait macules and neurofibromas; otherwise, 
central neurofibromatosis (NF-2) develops eight nerve 
tumors and other intracranial and intraspinal tumors as 
well. There are no specific treatments for neurofibroma tosis, but treatment involves alleviation of the clinical 
symptoms. In this case, we report a rare case of a neu rofibroma with over 20 cm in dimension in the maxillo facial region, which deforms the patient’s face and

Case presentation
Medical history
In November 2023, a Rag-lay ethnic woman aged 30 years 
was brought to Cho Ray Hospital with an overhanging 
mass on the left side of her face. Medical history revealed 
that the disease started in her childhood, but she did not 
seek medical care due to economic constraints. Multi ple cutaneous neurofibromas appeared 10 years ago and 
grew gradually throughout the body. It is noteworthy that 
there was a rapid growth of a tumor on the left side of 
the maxillofacial region. Furthermore, the tumor invaded 
the left eye socket and temporal bone causing vision loss. 
One week before hospital admission, the deformed mass 
started bleeding continuously. There was a negative fam ily history.
Physical examination
On the initial physical examination, she had severe mal nutrition (body mass index: 17.1 kg/m2), and the left 
side of her face was deformed by a large tumor (meas ured about 15 cm × 20 cm). Her facial mass involved the 
eyelids, cheek, and temple; but did not affect the lips 
and chin (Fig.  1). The eye examination showed vision impairment due to ocular atrophy. We found that she had 
hundreds of soft cutaneous neurofibromas all over her 
body as seen in Fig.  2. The skin examination also revealed 
multiple café-au-lait macules and freckling spots (Fig.  3). 
No other clinical findings were identified.
Laboratory test
Moderate chronic anemia was detected by blood tests 
(decreased hemoglobin [Hgb] 10.5  g/dl, decreased

hematocrit [Hct] 33%) with normal platelet and coagula tion function. The routine laboratory tests were in a nor mal range.
Craniofacial computed tomography (CT) scan con firmed a deforming mass on the left temporal region of 
her face infiltrating the orbit and temporal bone (Fig.  4). 
The nature of the tumor was characterized by increased 
blood vessel density with subcutaneous hematoma.
Histopathologic findings on biopsy samples showed 
the tumor nature of peripheral nerve and connective tis sue. The nature of the deforming mass was analyzed and 
described as spindle and thin cells with hyperchromatic 
nuclei arranged in parallel bundles.
Diagnosis
Neurofibromatosis diagnosis is typically based on clini cal symptoms, particularly when specialized features of 
NF-1 are present. This patient was diagnosed with NF-1 
(plexiform variant) based on two criteria [2]. The patient 
refused to undergo genetic testing.
Treatment
The main treatment for this patient is surgical resection 
of the deformed mass. However, the challenge was the 
complexity of the deforming mass that invaded the eye 
socket, the temporal bone, and meninges causing atro phy of the eyeball and brain herniation. Furthermore, the tumor was in a state of bleeding (Fig.  5). In the first 
attempt of care, the ophthalmologist removed her left 
eyeball.
Vascular intervention: About 7 days after admission, 
vascular specialists utilized coil embolization under 
the digital subtraction angiography (DSA) to cut off the 
blood supply to the tumor. Since there was still blood 
supply after coil intervention based on the computed 
tomographic angiography (CTA) images, the vascular

specialists decided to ligate the external carotid artery 
2 days after coil embolization (Fig. 6 ).
Neurosurgery: Right after the vascular intervention, 
neurosurgeons sutured torn meninges in the frontal 
region and orbital roof.
Plastic surgery: The deforming mass was taken out by 
plastic surgeons and the facial skin fold was recreated in 
the same operation as the neurosurgery (Fig. 7).
Patient outcome
Vascular surgery, neurosurgery, and plastic surgery were 
the three specialties involved in the patient’s surgery. 
Immediately after the surgery, the patient recovered 
well, and her appearance was improved as seen in Fig.  8. 
She received follow-up after being discharged to screen 
for subsequent malignancy. Her good outcome resulted 
from the success of the surgery and careful preoperative 
preparation. According to the patient’s niece, the patient 
originated from an ethnic minority and poor families. 
Furthermore, they had difficulty in seeking healthcare 
services. The patient had been sick for many years and 
suffered from the deformed mass on her face and psy chological matters due to disfigurement. Since the tumor 
was bleeding for a long time, the family took her to the 
doctor. After the resection of the tumor, we found that 
the patient was in good mental and physical condition. 
The patient and her family were satisfied with the surgical 
outcomes.Discussion
Plexiform neurofibromas account for 30% of NF-1 
cases, and the term “plexiform neurofibroma” arises 
from the description of a network-like growth of the 
mass. The nature of PNF is diffuse and soft, involv ing nerve fibers surrounded by a connective matrix. 
The tumor could occur at any location along the nerve 
but was more likely to be in the maxillofacial region. 
Neurofibroma could be divided into massive plexi form, cranio-orbital, and cervical neurofibromas. The 
hemifacial deforming mass of the face, as observed in 
the presenting case, was classified as cranio-orbital 
neurofibroma.
The tumor’s location may affect the clinical features 
[3]. Main symptoms could be ocular motility distur bances or more severely ocular atrophy in this patient, 
respiratory failure due to upper airway obstruction, 
neurological deficits due to cranial nerve depression, 
and psychological problems such as facial disfigure ment. Café au lait spots are macules that vary in color 
from light to dark brown with smooth or irregular bor ders. These spots could appear all over the body but are 
less common on the face. The presence of multiple neu rofibromas is a distinguishing attribute of NF-1.
Diagnosis of neurofibromatosis is easily made on a clin ical basis, especially when classical hallmarks are present. 
Classical features of NF-1 include specific skin lesions 
(café au lait macules and freckling spots on the armpit) 
and the growth of benign tumors along the course of the

nerve. In 1990, the National Institutes of Health (NIH) 
recommended diagnostic criteria for NF-1: [2]
1. Six or more café-au-lait spots > 5 mm in prepubertal 
patients or > 15 mm in post pubertal patients.
2. Two or more neurofibromas of any type or a plexi form neurofibromas.
3. Ephelides in axillary and inguinal regions.
4. Two or more Lish nodules.
5. A characteristic bone lesion, such as sphenoid bone 
dysplasia or thinning of the cortex of long bones, 
with or without pseudoarthrosis.
6. Incomplete status, but having a first-degree relative 
(parent, brother, or son) who meets NIH criteria.
7. Two or more criteria are needed for diagnostic con firmation of NF.
Diagnosis of NF-1 in this patient is based on clinical 
presentation, histological results, and computed tomog raphy scan of the mass. CT images confirmed plexiform 
neurofibroma in the maxillofacial region. Histological 
examination of biopsy samples showed hyperplasia of 
spindle and thin cells with hyperchromatic nuclei. These 
cells were organized in parallel bundles. Furthermore, the 
histological results confirmed no evidence of malignancy, 
which is rather important for this disorder. Bone involve ment in this patient is related to external resorption 
involving the destruction of orbital bone and skull base 
with meningeal rupture. The cause of external resorp tion is thought to be the result of plexiform neurofibroma 
pressure. In the typical case of NF-1, bone malformations 
of kyphoscoliosis or pseudoarthrosis might involve the 
temporomandibular joint [4].
Treatment guidelines for plexiform neurofibroma are 
still surgery [5]. These kinds of tumors are not sensitive 
to radiotherapy and patients do not receive benefits from 
chemotherapy. Some cases had treatment indications 
for visual decline, progressive tumor growth relating to 
vital structure, and disfigurement or functional decline 
[6]. Although resection surgery is the main therapy, it is 
advised to choose the appropriate time of surgery. The 
ideal time is in adulthood when the tumor stops grow ing. Another issue is the selection of total or partial 
resection. Friedrich reported nine cases of PNF that had 
no neurological or functional deficit were qualified for 
total resection [7]. This case was scheduled for surgery 
due to complications of bleeding and a deforming mass 
that affects the vision. Her tumor might stop growing 
and its condition was qualified for total resection. Inter disciplinary collaboration was required in the surgery. 
Coil embolization and external carotid artery ligation 
were utilized to address the tumor’s abundant blood sup ply. Furthermore, the torn meninges were sutured, and the face was restored via skin grafting after resection. 
Another aspect is the recurrence rate and the concerns 
of malignant transformation in recurrent tumors. As 
we know, the rate of recurrence ranged from 20 to 40% 
in total resection and incomplete surgery, respectively.
At the follow-up, it identified 4-5 percent of malignant 
tumors. Therefore, a close follow-up is required for the 
patient after surgical excision.
Conclusions
Plexiform neurofibroma of the presented case deformed 
the patient’s face, invading the left eye socket causing eye ball atrophy, and penetrating the temporal bone resulting 
in meningeal rupture and brain herniation. Addition ally, the deforming mass had an abundant blood supply 
system creating the challenge of surgical resection. Suc cessful treatment highlighted the role of endovascular 
intervention, neurosurgery, and flap reconstruction sur gery. Potential implications of the presented case could 
be summarized as a detailed clinical evaluation, careful 
interdisciplinary consultation before the operation, vas cular intervention to cut off the tumor’s blood supply, and 
skin fold regeneration to improve facial disfigurement.
